thread.title: 5 movies at the Philadelphia Film Fest you can't see anywhere else
thread.title_full: 5 movies at the Philadelphia Film Fest you can't see anywhere else

author: Gary Thompson
title: 5 movies at the Philadelphia Film Fest you can't see anywhere else
text:
Entertainment 5 movies at the Philadelphia Film Fest you can't see anywhere else Here are five buzzed-about movies that do not (yet) have theatrical distribution, so you can see them locally on the big screen only at the Film Festival. 5 movies at the Philadelphia Film Fest you can't see anywhere else DJ AM performs during the party at Shrine for The MGM Grand Opening at Foxwoords at the MGM Grand at Foxwoods Resort & Casino on May 17, 2008 in Ledyard, Connecticut. Photo by Astrid Stawiarz/Getty Images Travel Deals Filed Under: Movies 
Here are five buzzed-about movies that do not (yet) have theatrical distribution, so you can see them locally on the big screen only at the Film Festival. 
THE HIGH SUN The recipient of the Un Certain Regard Jury Prize at the 2015 Cannes Film Festival took home the honor for its complex look at the fallout from ethnic wars in the former Yugoslavia, between 1991 to 2011. The story is told from the standpoint of six people and three love stories. In the process, Croatian director Dalibor Matanic manages to convey what was once possible, what was lost, and the unhealed scars that remain. 
2:15 p.m., Oct. 29; 12:20 p.m., Oct. 30, Ritz East, 125 S. 2nd St. 
GUILTY 
Wonderful Pakistani actor Irrfan Khan (Slumdog Millionaire, Life of Pi) has the lead here in this well-crafted procedural based on what one of India's most notorious murders, playing the police inspector who works tirelessly to solve the case. 
5 p.m., Oct. 28; 7:10 p.m., Nov. 1; Ritz East 
(T)ERROR In the recent tradition of The Newburgh Sting and Better This World, this mind-bending documentary starts with a pretty good "get" _ an FBI informant paid to target a suspected homegrown terrorist. The movie ratchets up when the filmmakers start interviewing the suspected terrorist, without the knowledge of the informant or the FBI. A rough-hewn work that nonetheless gives insight into the chaotic and morally murky world of counterterrorism. 
12:25 p.m., Saturday; 9:10 p.m., Nov. 1; Ritz at the Bourse, 400 Ranstead St. 
600 MILES In the wake of Sicario, here's another thriller set amid the guns-and-drugs chaos of the U.S./Mexico border. An ATF agent (Tim Roth) ends up in the enforced company of a Mexican man running guns to a cartel in exchange for drugs. Director Gabriel Ripstein won the the Best First Feature award at the Berlin Film Festival, and is Mexico's official entry submission for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film at the 88th Academy Awards. 
12:15 pm, Friday; 9:35 pm, Nov. 1; Ritz East 
AS I AM: THE LIFE AND TIMES OF DJ AM DJ AM was Adam Michael Goldstein, a Philadelphia native and Friends Central grad whose stranger-than-fiction life forms the narrative of this frenetic documentary. The movie charts his troubled upbringing, his addiction, his love of music, his rise to fame as DJ, and his celebrity romance with Nicole Richie. He survived that, and a plane crash, but eventually succumbed to addiction, making As I Am a melancholy bookend to the arthouse hit Amy. 
4:30 p.m., Oct. 27; 7:15 p.m., Oct. 29; Ritz Bourse __
